newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee called to open 1.00 to 2.00 lower.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee called to open 1.00 to 2.00 lower.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures were called to open 1.00 to 2.00 cents per lb lower on Wednesday, as a build in U.S. consumer coffee stocks during June is expected to weigh on sentiment, traders said.
The Green Coffee Association of New York report after Tuesday's close that supplies of green coffee stowed in U.S. warehouses rose in June by 139,000 60-kg bags, to 2,116,000 bags.

Traders and analysts said the increase was mostly within expectations, with most estimates coming in at plus or minus 100,000 bags, although some market participants had predicted a build of up to 200,000 bags.
They said a build-up in inventories was partially priced in the market after Tuesday's fall to more than three-month lows.
"I think among the trade it was expected," one dealer said regarding the increase in GCA stocks. "But you might see some spec selling off the number."

Speculative selling pressured New York arabica futures for the second day in a row on Tuesday, with September falling 4.15 cents, to 157.85 cents, after ranging between 159.50 and 156.25 cents. Spot July, which expires in less than a week, ended 2.50 cents lower, at 184.50 cents, while the outer months closed down 0.05 to 3.60 cents.
The July/September switch widened to 26.65 cents compared with 25.00 cents at the close on Monday, while the September/December switch narrowed to 11.95 cents from 12.50 cents.
After the close on Tuesday, CSCE reported certified coffee stocks in the U.S. warehouses fell for the first time in more than a week, dipping 100 60-kg bags as of July 14, to 72,145 bags.
However, there were an additional 36,182 bags pending grading, the exchange said.

On the weather front, U.S.-based forecaster Weather Services Corp said on Wednesday that there is no damaging cold weather expected this week in Brazil's coffee belt, with the lowest temperatures in major coffee-growing areas likely to remain above 50 F (10 C) through Monday.
Technically, traders said the September contract would run into some chart support at 155.00 cents, followed by 150.00 cents. On the upside, they said September faced resistance at 160.00 cents.

London robusta futures slumped early Wednesday on continued speculative selling, but managed to recover off lows. At the midday break, benchmark September was down $39 at $1,546, after ranging from $1,586 to $1,530 -- its lowest level since February 25.
